p: RSV can be divided into two distinct subgroups (RSV-A and RSV-B) ( Mufson et al., 1985). Subgroups can be further divided into genotypes based on the gene sequence variability of the second hypervariable region (HVR2) located on the distal third region of the G gene ( Melero, Mas & McLellan, 2017). As a result, there are 13 RSV-A genotypes: GA1 to GA7Â ( Peret et al., 2000), SAA1 ( Venter et al., 2001), NA1 to NA4 ( Shobugawa et al., 2009; Cui et al., 2013), and ON1 ( Eshaghi et al., 2012). To date, 22 RSV-B genotypes are GB1 to GB4 ( Peret et al., 2000), SAB1 to SAB4 ( Venter et al., 2001; Arnott et al., 2011), URU1 and URU2 ( Blanc et al., 2005), BA1 to BA10 ( Trento et al., 2006), BA-C ( Cui et al., 2013), and THB ( Auksornkitti et al., 2014).
